source.citation: Peterson, J.T. 1988. A Case Study of Roadside Logging in the Central Interior of British Columbia. FERIC Technical Report TR-87.
notes: Roadside CTL-style system west of Quesnel: FB221 feller-buncher, JD 740A grapple skidder, two Timberjack TJ90 processors, and a Caterpillar LL229 loader.
Study captured day vs. night shift performance plus combined averages (22 082 m³ processed, 24 146 m³ harvested).
Processing costs derived by FERIC (Table 14) exclude interest/overhead and were reported at $2.67/m³ with $641/day machine rates in 1987 CAD.

scenarios.name: tj90_day_shift
scenarios.description: TJ90 #1 processor on day shift handling feller-bunched, grapple-yarded windrows (aligned stems, level ground).
notes: Includes waits for wood when the single feller-buncher could not keep ahead of processing demand.
Tree mix averaged 1.32 m³/stem (spruce/pine) with single-log outputs per stem.

scenarios.name: tj90_night_shift
scenarios.description: TJ90 #1 processor on night shift; higher per-PMH output but low utilisation because felled inventory starved the processor.
notes: Night shift suffered long wait-for-wood delays until a second feller-buncher was added later in the study.

scenarios.name: tj90_combined_observed
scenarios.description: Observed average for TJ90 #1 across day + night shifts (52.6% utilisation overall).
notes: Matches Table 8 combined column for TJ90 #1 (m³/PMH 36.8, utilisation 63%).

scenarios.name: tj90_both_processors_observed
scenarios.description: Combined throughput of both TJ90 processors (22 082 m³ over 74 tracked shifts).
notes: Represents the actual two-processor configuration before wait-for-wood mitigation.

scenarios.name: tj90_both_processors_wait_adjusted
scenarios.description: Same as combined scenario but with wait-for-wood delays removed (FERIC’s planning recommendation).
notes: Aligns with Table 8’s ‘Utilization — wait-for-wood removed’ line (76%) and the recommended 240 m³/shift processor target once a second feller-buncher balances the system.
